Abiar is 28 years old and married. She has three children, none of whom is in school. She has been selling fish in Bor, South Sudan for five years.

Abiar is requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase more fish to sell. She will save her extra income from this loan to build a house someday.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve on business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her grocery shop business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase merchandise in bulk.

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Mrs. Em N. is 42 years old widow and lives with her daughter in  Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is a landlord and can typically earn around three dollars per day from her different rooms. Due to an increased demand from her tenants, Em N. is recently asking for a loan to build more rooms. She is therefore requesting a loan.

loans.use: To build more rooms to earn rental income

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Mrs. Helen O. is a member of the Nosakhore LAPO union in the Benin branch. Helen is 38 years old and married with a child. She has been with LAPO for 6 years and has been in this business since 2000. She is seeking a $475 loan to buy bags of rice, groundnut oil and other foodstuffs for sale.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Huy

texts.en: Mrs. Huy I., age 21, is a housewife. Her husband sells sand and stone for construction, earning about $10 per day in revenue. They have one child, who is very young. In order to expand her husband's business and increase the volume of materials sold, she would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase a truck to transport the construction materials. This will allow hI. to fulfill larger orders and increase sales volume. They plan to use the additional income to reinvest in his business and save money for their child’s education.

loans.use: To purchase a truck to deliver construction materials.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: She will invest the loan in buying more products (El crédito lo invertirá en compra de más productos.)

loans.name: Dira A Group

texts.en:
Dafroza, age 26, is married with 1 child (age 4). She owns a business of making bread, which she began 1 year ago. She opens her business from 7am to 10am, and makes a monthly profit of about $136.

Dafroza hopes to take a loan with Tujijenge Tanzania to increase her business. She will be sharing this loan with her sub group members, who have businesses dealing in a retail shop, charcoal selling, livestock, and stationery.

In the picture, Dafroza is in the centre, front row.

loans.use: To increase business

loans.name: Abdulkosim

texts.en:
K. Abdulkosim is 25 years old and married. In spite of the fact that Abdulkosim does not have children yet, he is responsible for supporting a large family, consisting of six people, including his parents, younger brothers and sisters.

To earn a living, Abdulkosim sells confectionery and has been in this business for already five years. In addition, he raises cattle - currently, he owns a cow and a calf. These two businesses generate most of the income of Abdulkosim's family. 

Already popular in the neighborhood for selling the fresh and tasty pastries, Abdulkosim, nevertheless, would like to increase the range of the goods on his offer. Therefore, Abdulkosim is asking for a loan of US$600 for a term of 12 months in order to be able to purchase more confectionery for sale, as well as to buy fodder for the cattle.

loans.use: Purchase of confectionary for sale and of fodder for cattle

loans.name: Atungani's Bustani Group

texts.en:
Atungani is a 33-year-old married woman with two children, ages 7 and 5. Atungani is tailor; she started this business in 2006. Every day she works from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of about $60.

In the past, Atungani has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her tailoring business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses selling clothes and food.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Amal

texts.en: Amal is 37 years old and lives with her family in the Bekaa Valley. She has five children, and makes a living selling clothing to her neighbors. This is the second time she has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua. She will use the money to buy new merchandise to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy new merchandise to sell to her customers

loans.name: Marina's Group

texts.es:
Patrocinia, Marina and Marilia have been members of the communal bank of Chacco for 6 months, 1 year and 6 months respectively. They are from the community of Chacco which is located 30 minutes outside of the city of Ayacucho.

Patrocinia is 39 years old, and married with 4 children. She raises small animals to sell and also grows vegetables. Marina is 41 years and separated with 6 children. She sells baby chickens which she buys at various markets in the region. And Marilia is 20 years old and single. She sells drinks from a small shop she set up 6 months ago.

The women will use the loan to purchase stock for their respective businesses, including food for the animals, more chickens, sodas and drinks. Each of the women share the dream of growing their businesses and improving their homes.

Patrocinia, Marina y Marilia pertenecen al Banco Comunal Chacco hace 6 meses, 1 año, 6 meses respectivamente. Ellas son de la comunidad de Chacco que esta ubicado a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Patrocinia es casada, tiene 39 años y 4 hijos, Patrocinia se dedica a la crianza de animales y la agricultura de verduras.

Por otro lado Marina es separada, Marina tiene 41 años y 6 hijos, Marina vende pollos bebes, que compra de las granjas, en las diferentes ferias de la región.

Mientras que Marilia es soltera y tiene 20 años, Marilia tiene una tienda donde vende bebidas, actividad que inició hace 6 meses.

Patrocinia, Marina y Marilia necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 900 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de alimento para animales, pollo, cerveza y gaseosa.

Los sueños de Patrocinia, Marina y Marilia son mejorar sus negocios, tener una buena casa.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE STOCK FOR THEIR RESPECTIVE BUSINESSES SUCH AS SODAS, DRINKS, CHICKENS AND FEED FOR THE ANIMALS.

loans.name: Rin

texts.en: Rin Y. is 43 years old and lives as a housewife in Kampong Cham. She manages the house and cares for her four children while her husband runs a motor-taxi to pay the bills. He does quite well for his profession and earns 8 US$ per day. Their oldest son works in the trucking business as a conductor, organizing routes and negotiating pay. He contributes well to the family income, earning 60 US$ per month. Rin Y. would like to buy her husband a new motorbike for his taxi business during this time of financial stability so they will not have to replace the bike anytime soon. Rin Y.'s husband is pictured here as she was unavailable to be photographed.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Epifania

texts.es:
Mrs. Epifania is 56 years old, she lives in a neighborhood very close to the center of the city of Luque, she doesn't have children, and she dedicates herself to making clothes that she has been selling to businesses in the center of the city for a few years. In 2007, she began her own business of dressmaking, with notable success she already knows the activity and has many important contacts that help her with the sale of her clothes. She operates excellently with the Paraguayan Foundation; the loan that she solicits is for the purchase of fabrics, threads, and buttons in quantity enough to cover her requests for merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Epifania tiene 56 años de edad, vive en un barrio muy cercano al centro de la ciudad de Luque, no tiene hijos, se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir para comercios del centro de la ciudad desde hace varios años.

. En el año 2007, inició su propia empresa de confección, con un notable éxito ya que conocía la actividad y poseía contactos importantes que ayudaron a la venta de sus prendas.

La misma opera con la Fundación Paraguaya en forma excelente, el préstamo que solicita es para la compra de telas, hilos, botones en cantidad de manera a cubrir un pedido importante de mercaderías que tiene.

loans.use: Compra de tela, hilos, botones

loans.name: Fatma's Tusongembele Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 27 years old. Her husband has passed away, leaving her with 3 children, aged 11, 14, and 15. Fatma entered the charcoal and cake industry in 2006. She begins work everyday at 6 AM and ends at 6 PM, and earns around $20 a month in profits from her business.

In the past, Fatma has successfully completed one loan from BRAC Tanzania. She used the money to expand her business, and she would like to continue to do so. She will also share her loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in food, charcoal, and firewood sales.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and charcoal to increase her stock.

loans.name: Kidawa's Tabia Njema Group

texts.en:
Kidawa is 31 years old and is divorced with an 8 year old child. She has been selling shoes and ladies and children's clothing since 2005. She works everyday from 8am to 6pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $43 from her sales.

In the past, Kidawa has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Kidawa now requests a new loan to buy more shoes and clothing for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who also has a business selling shoes, clothes and cosmetics.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and clothing inventory for her business.

loans.name: Akofa

texts.fr: Célibataire  et mère d’un enfant, Akofa K. est née le 02/10/1982 à Lomé. Elle habite le quartier Bè Ahligo . Elle a un salon de coiffure qui ne répond pas aux normes pour la satisfaction de ses clients et lui fournissant suffisamment de revenus pour subvenir à ses propres besoins et celui de son enfant. Elle sollicite ce crédit pour s’équiper en matériel de travail et en produits cosmétiques et rénover son salon de coiffure.
texts.en:
A single mother with one child, Akofa K. was born on Oct 2, 1982 in Lomé. She lives in the Bè Ahligo district. She has a hairdressing salon that is unable to satisfy its customers or provide her with enough income to meet her own needs or those of her child. She is requesting this loan to equip herself with work materials and cosmetic products, and to renovate her hairdressing salon.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase work materials and renovate her hairdressing salon

loans.name: Jhon Wingler

texts.es:
Wingler, como muchos le conocen, tiene 20 años, soltero, es un joven emprendedor y empeñoso, aporta con los gastos familiares, ya que como hijo mayor, representa el papel de padre y tiene que sacar adelante a su hermanito de 10 años edad. Se dedica al transporte de pasajeros desde hace varios años atrás, y ya es propietario de un motocarro.  
Su deseo, tiene que ver con su madre, solicita el préstamo para construir al costado de su vivienda un local para la venta de comida, que estará a cargo su mamá, la señora Norma, quien se siente orgullosa de su hijo. Para Wingler, no existe nada imposible, ya que hará todo lo posible para lograr su objetivo. Además, parte del dinero obtenido, lo usará también, en la compra de repuestos para el arreglo de su motocarro. Con tu apoyo, lograremos cumplir el propósito de este joven en un tiempo muy breve.
texts.en:
Wingler, as many know, is 20 years old, single, and a young, hard working entrepreneur. He helps out with the household costs, and since he is the oldest child, plays the part of father and must succeed for his younger, 10 year old brother. He has worked as a passenger transport for several years now, and owns an auto. He desires, on behalf of his mother, a loan to construct an area to sell food in the back of their home. The store would be in the charge of his mother, Norma, who is very proud of her son. For Wingler, nothing is impossible, since he will do everything possible to achieve his goals. In addition, Wingler will aslo use part of the loan obtained to purchase the parts needed to repair his auto. With your support, we will accomplish the goal of the young man in a very short period of time.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his auto, an construct a location in their home for his mother to sell pepared food.

loans.name: Phally's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phally S. is a group leader of six who all live in Romon Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a hectare and cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Choem Thy, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make a small income to support his family. Aside from this business, he is a pig breeder who raises two pigs. Since this business is going well and he wants to expand it, his wife, Mrs. Phally S., decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding.

Mrs. Phally S. is 35 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom is a laborer while three others are attending the local school. The remaining two are too young to work or study because they are two and five years old.

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK’s main product and are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor because they allow loan recipients to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Jenry Omar

texts.en:
Jenry Omar is working his way through university. With his childhood dream of becoming a professional now within reach, he is asking for a loan of 400 Soles to pay his upcoming school fees. Jenry has always wanted to study to become a medical technician but has also always had to work. 

From a very young age when he worked in a bakery, he has been in a number of odd jobs. Currently, Jenry works three days a week as a "cobrador" (in Peru's informal transportation business, the person on buses and vans who tell the driver when to stop to pick up passengers and when to go, announce stops, and collect passengers' fares). 

He wants to be licensed as a medical technician, however, to do that he still needs to get his título (certificate), which takes a year. He plans on continuing his transportation job when he's a medical technician but hopes he'll have enough to own his own car and run it as a taxi when needed. 

With this loan, Jenry Omar will be one step closer to his life goals of owning his own house, business, and working as a licensed medical technician.

loans.use: To pay for school fees to become a medical technician

loans.name: Zaur

texts.en: Zaur was born in 1981, is married, and lives in the city of Baku. He has been in this business for 4 years. Now, he needs a loan to buy the necessary things to improve his business.

loans.use: To improve his business

loans.name: Sharifjon

texts.en:
Since he was a boy, Sharifjon has loved animals. He has learned to raise them well so that he can market them. Sharifjon is married and has 4 children to provide for. To support his family, he has to invest in his livestock business and, consequently, he's approached IMON International to apply for a loan that will allow him to purchase calves and feed for them, which will, in turn, increase his income from the milk, meat, horns, etc. that cattle provide.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand his business

loans.name: Santa Honorata

texts.es:
Santa Honorata es una mujer de 40 años, vive con sus 2 hijos, su esposo y sus padres en el  distrito de Huaraz. Nos cuenta que le gustaría independizarse como familia ya que la casa donde viven es de sus padres.

Desde muy niña observaba el trabajo de sus padres, ellos se dedicaban al molino; es así que a los 30 años a Santa le nace la idea de vender harina de los granos que se procesan en el molino (granos de quinua, habas, cebada, linaza, y otras variedades).

Actualmente, Santa de hombro a hombro con su esposo, trabajan en el Mercado 19 de Marzo vendiendo harinas de habas, quinua, avena, yuca y además muestra desenvolvimiento en su negocio, tiene clientes fidelizados que siempre la buscan y la reclaman cuando no sale a vender. Además de vender en el mercado informal, ella participa en licitaciones de harinas del PRONAA (Entidad del estado), que le exigen estándares de calidad.

Santa pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Catalina de Monterrey”.
Con este crédito de S/. 1,500 que será cancelado en 6 meses, Santa comprará 15 sacos de trigo para el stock.
texts.en:
Santa Honorata, 40, lives with her husband, two children and her parents in her parents' house in the district of Huaraz. She tells us that her family would like to be able to move out of her parents' home. As a child, she watched her parents' work in their mill. At 30, Santa came up with the idea of selling flour made out of the different grains that are processed on the mill (quinoa, fava beans, barley, flaxseed and others.) Now Santa and her husband works shoulder to shoulder at the market selling the different kinds of flour. Her business show progress, and she already has customers that look for her products and missed her when she does not come to the market. Besides selling informally at the market, Santa participates in state bids to provide flour, which requires her flour to meet quality standards. Santa is a member of the communal bank “Santa Catalina de Monterrey”. With this loan of 1,500 soles, to be paid back in 6 months, Santa will purchase 15 sack of wheat to stock her growing business.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing grains wholesale

loans.name: Doris

texts.es: Doris de 42 años, vive con su esposo y sus hijos en una casa alquilada donde ha puesto su negocio, lo que ella más quiere es poderle dar a sus hijos buenos estudios y que con el tiempo sean unos buenos profesionales. Doris incursionó en el negocio de los tratamientos estéticos hace 20 años, la contrataban en distintos salones de belleza, pero hace 6 años por fin pudo juntar el dinero necesario para poner su propio local, realiza cortes de cabello, manicuras, coloraciones, rizados, etc, tiene muchos clientes, ya que es muy buena en lo que hace y disfruta de aconsejar a sus clientes sobre el corte o el color de pelo que mejor le quedará. Doris tiene un sueño muy grande, desea tener un Spa donde pueda brindar un servicio más completo, lo que menos le gusta de su trabajo son los fuertes olores que dejan los tintes, lo cual hace que por momentos tenga que detener su trabajo y esperar a que los fuertes químicos desaparezcan, aun así no declina en su afán de mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP y está segura de poder pagarlo a tiempo y sin complicaciones, ya que no quiere ocasionarle problemas a sus socias del banco comunal donde participa activamente. Doris planea invertir el dinero que solicita en la compra de más productos estéticos, con los cuales pueda brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Doris is 42 years old and lives with her husband and their children in a rented house where she has set up her business. What she wants most is to provide her children with a good education so that they will become good professionals someday. Doris began her business of aesthetic treatments 20 years ago, working in various beauty salons. Six years ago, she finally pulled together the necessary funds to open her own place, where she does haircuts, manicures, dyeing, perms, etc. She has many customers, as she is very good at what she does and enjoys consulting them about the cut or color that best suits them. Doris has a very big dream--she wishes to have a spa where she can provide more complete services. What she likes least about her work is the strong odors given off by the dyes, which sometimes require her to leave her work and wait until the strong chemicals disappear. Even still, she doesn't shy away from hard work, because she wants to improve her family's quality of life. This is her first loan with MFP, and she is certain that she will be able to make her repayments on time and without complications, since she doesn't want cause any problems with the members of the communal bank in which she actively participates. Doris plans to invest the money in the purchase of more beauty products, with which she can give her customers better service.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products for beauty salon

loans.name: Sona

texts.en: Sona (her husband is pictured) was born in 1952. She is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli region. She is settled in the Kayidish village, built for IDPs. This family has been in the farming business for 10 years. Now they need a loan of 2000 AZN to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides for improving their farming business. They have 2 children.

loans.use: To buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Sosefina

texts.en:
Sosefina P., 34, is married with two children. She has one year of experience in the popcorn business. She sells to the village people six days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (about $49).

SPBD loans are Sosefina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks, and this is her first SPBD loan. She wishes to use it to purchase corn, an oven, a frying pan, oil, and plastic bags.

loans.use: To purchase corn, an oven, a frying pan, oil, and plastic bags.

loans.name: Karla Patricia

texts.es: La señora Karla Patricia O. se dedica ala venta de ropa, cosmético, perfumenes desde hace ocho años. Tiene 35 años de edad, reside en el barrio Anexo Riguero en la capital de Managua, tiene cuatro hijos de 3, 7,14 y 16 años de edad, los cuales estudian, su esposo es cadete de taxi. Su negocio lo inicio con dinero propio, con este crédito quiere invertir en la compra productos de cosmético, ropa y productos de consumo diario para la pulpería, y poder vender mas. Sus planes es poder aumentar su inventario, para crecer y así ayudar a sus hijos que estudien.
texts.en:
For the past eight years Karla Patricia O. has made a living selling clothing, cosmetics, and perfume. She is 35 years old, and lives in the Anexo Riguero neighborhood in the capital, Managua. She has four children, ages 3, 7, 14, and 16, all of whom are in school. Her husband is a taxi driver. She started her business with her own money, and wants to use this loan to invest in the purchase of cosmetic products, clothing, and products for daily consumption so that she can sell more at her small store. Her plan is to increase her inventory so that her business will grow and thus help her school-age children.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cosmetics and products for daily consumption to increase her inventory

loans.name: Soberana Group

texts.es:
Foto De izquierda a derecha: Margarita de los Angeles M. R., María Antonia S. G. y Josefa del Carmen P. V..

Les presento al grupo solidario Soberana, conformado por las señoras María Antonia S. G., quien se dedica a la elaboración y venta de pan, la otra integrante es la señora Josefa del Carmen P. V., quien realiza  la activad de elaboración y venta de comida casera, refrescos naturales y jugos enlatados, y la señora Margarita de los Angeles, cuya activad económica es la venta de Zapatos de mujer estas mujeres son muy trabajadoras, emprendedoras, responsables, y semi-analfabetas, pero con muchos deseos de superación. Estas señoras abonan todos los Lunes, es el mejor día para abonar, después del fin de semana que las ventas son mejores. 


Doña Josefa del Carmen P. V., es una mujer de 31 años de edad, casada, madre de tres hijos, los cuales tiene las edades de 12, 7 y 6 años. Su negocio es la elaboración de venta de comida, para el desayuno, almuerzo y cena, dentro del menú se encuentran platillos tales como el tradicional gallo pinto, nacatamales, carne, pollo y cerdo asado, tajadas con queso, etc. Trabaja con Adim porque una de las clientas le animó que se integrará en un grupo solidario, así ella conformó su grupo con dos amigas cercanas y obtuvo el préstamo. El esposo de doña Josefa, se dedica a la manufactura de zapatos en un pequeño taller, cercano a su localidad. Piensa que con el crédito va a salir adelante, para seguir incrementando su negocio que siempre necesita de capital extra.
texts.en:
Photo from left to right: Margarita de los Angeles M. R., María Antonia S. G. y Josefa del Carmen P. V.. Meet the supportive Soberana group. María Antonia S. G. makes and sells bread. Another member, Josefa del Carmen P. V., sells home-made food, natural soft drinks, and canned juices. Margarita de los Angeles sells women’s shoes. These women are very hard working, enterprising, and responsible. They are semi-literate, but they have great desires to improve. These women shop every Monday; it is the best day to stock up, after the week end the sales are better. Josefa del Carmen P. V. is 31 and married. She has three children ages 12, 7, and 6. She sells breakfast, lunch, and dinner. On the menu you will find dishes like the traditional rice and beans, tamales, meat, roasted chicken and pork, tajadas (fried plantain slices) with cheese, etc. She works with Adim because one of the customers encouraged her to join a supportive group. She formed her group with two close friends and got a loan. Josefa’s husband manufactures shoes in a small shop close to her place. With this loan she plans to get ahead by continuing to increase her business that always needs extra capital.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pastries, soft drinks, corn, etc.

loans.name: Rosmery

texts.es:
La señora Rosmery, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Cuidad de los Tres Pisos”, vive en Jr. Ancohallo Nº 216, Provincia de Lamas, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 55 años, madre de 05 hijos ya independientes.

Es docente de Inicial, en un principio estuvo trabajando y ejerciendo su carrera, pero nos comenta que dejo de trabajar, ya que se quedo sin puesto de trabajo.
Le nace la idea de independizarse y generar sus propios ingresos, así que decidió implementar su negocio de venta de comidas, poco a poco fue ganando experiencia en este tipo de actividad y haciéndose muy conocida y querida entre sus clientes.  
En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio atendiendo a sus clientes que a diario acuden a su restaurant y es ella quien personalmente los atiende con su rica sazón y el carisma alegre que tiene. 

Con este préstamo de S/ 2,000.00, desea invertirlo comprando arroz y azúcar en sacos, diversas verduras,  huevos y pollos en javas. También comprará algunos utensilios de cocina, para reemplazar a los que tiene actualmente y así brindar un mejor servicio de atención a sus clientes. 

Rosmery, se siente muy segura y con ganas de seguir adelante y asegurarse una  vida tranquila y  agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Señora Rosmery belongs to the communal bank, "Cuidad de los Tres Pisos," and lives in the province of Lamas in the department of San Martín. She is single, is 55-years-old, and is the mother of 5 children who are already independent. She is a preschool teacher. At first she was working but she tells us that she stopped working since she lost her job. She had the idea to become independent and generate her own income, which is why she decided to start a business of selling food. Little by little she earned experience in this work and now she is very well-known and loved by her customers. Currently she continues with her same business attending to her customers who come to her restaurant daily. She personally attends to them with her good cooking and charisma. With this loan of 2,000 PEN, she hopes to invest in the purchase of rice and sugar in sacks, various types of vegetables, eggs, and chickens. She also will buy kitchen utensils to replace those she has currently and to be able to offer better service to her customers. Rosmery feels very certain that she will get ahead and has a strong desire to do so. She wants to secure a peaceful life, and she is thankful to Manuela Ramos for contributing to her being able to fulfill her dreams and goals.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will purchase supplies (rice, sugar, and various types of vegetables) to prepare her food.

loans.name: Clotilde

texts.es:
La socia Clotilde, pertenece al banco comunal “SIEMPRE UNIDOS”, es natural del barrio de santiago en la ciudad del Cusco.

La socia tiene 60 años de edad,  es separada y alterna sus actividades del hogar con la compra y venta de joyas casa por casa, ella también visita instituciones y lleva sus joyas y las ofrece, luego al cabo de 15 días a un mes, cuando se acerca la fecha de pago de los trabajadores, ella va a cobrarles, este tipo de trabajo lo viene haciendo para cubrir sus necesidades y para que se sienta útil, manifiesta nuestra socia, para lo cual requiere el préstamo para poder comprar más joyas y exponerlas en las diferentes instituciones.

Nuestra socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Clotilde belongs to the "Siempre Unidos" ("Always United") Community Bank and is a native of the Santiago neighborhood in the city of Cusco, Peru. She is 60 years old, separated from her husband, and alternates her activities from her household obligations to buying and selling jewelry door to door. She also visits institutions and brings her jewelry to offer them up, and then can charge the workers after their payday. She does this type of work in order to meet her needs and to feel useful, she says. She is requesting the loan to be able to purchase more jewelry and display them at the different institutions. She is very grateful for this opportunity and promises to fulfill her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase jewelry to sell

loans.name: Desimforados S

texts.en:
Desimforados D. is from the village of Sulipat, Calamba Mis. Occidental. She is 40 years old. Desimforados is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Desimforados owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of food products in the local community. Desimforados has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (about $42 US) a month for these activities.

In 2007, Desimforados joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Desimforados has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 pesos from PMPC. Desimforados is requesting a new loan of 6,000 pesos which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Desimforados from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For growing corn

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena A. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old. Rowena is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Rowena owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different personal-care products like cosmetics in the local community. Rowena is just starting this business.

In 2009, Rowena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Rowena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora B. is from the village of Seti in Jimenez,Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old. Flora is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Flora raises pigs. Flora is just starting this business.

In 2008, Flora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000.00 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional animals. Flora is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional animals. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Flora from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional animals

loans.name: Jose De La Cruz

texts.es: José de la Cruz Narváez M. tiene 28 años, es un  joven muy dedicado a su trabajo. La actividad económica a la que se dedica es una pulpería hace mas de 5 años que se dedica a este trabajo. El tiene 2 hijos a su cargo, y con su esposa luchan juntos para proporcionarles a sus hijos lo necesario. Inicialmente solo ofrecía jugos, bolistas y pan ya que no tenía el capital suficiente para salir adelante pero José es un hombre muy luchador y siempre su Mama le enseño a que debía de trabajar de manera muy honrada y administrando el negocio de una manera muy adecuada. El solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de granos básicos, pan, jugos, refrescos naturales, golosinas y productos de limpieza. El sueño de José es proporcionarle mejoras a su vivienda.
texts.en:
José de la Cruz Narváez M. is 28 years old and dedicated to his work. He has managed a grocery store for more than 5 years. With two children to support, he and his wife struggle to provide everything they need. At first he only offered juices, popsicles and bread because he did not have sufficient capital for his business to get ahead. However, José is a fighter. His mother always taught him how to work honorably and manage his business effectively.

The loan he is requesting will be used as operating capital to buy basic grains, bread, juices, natural beverages, candy, and cleaning supplies. José dreams of making improvements to his home.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to restock his store with more merchandise

loans.name: Mrs. Teang Y Peng Village Bank Group

texts.en: A village bank loA. which consists of fifteen people is located in CH. Koah Kor village in Kandal province and all the members will use the loA. in different purposes. Mrs. Teang Y P. is the village bank president. She and her husband, Mr. Touch S., are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate vegetables. In this plantation, they face A. obstacle because they do not have money for growing. In order to deal this problem, Mrs. Teang Y P. decided to request a loA. to add her saving to grow beA. on the field. She is 45 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school and the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To request a loan to add her saving to grow bean on the field.

loans.name: Rogull Zaya Jan Group

texts.en:
This is the Rogull Zaya J. Group. There are four members in this group, and the group leader is Rogull. She is married and has six children. Four of her daughters are in school and two daughters are married. She wants to take a loan for her embroidery business to buy a new embroidery machine in order to make higher quality work.

Mah Gull also wants to take a loan for her son who is in the business of selling cosmetics. He wants to expand and grow his business.

Zaya J. wants to take a loan for her husband’s general store to purchase the required materials for the store.

The last member is Shokorya who wants to take a loan for her tailoring business to make a new shop.

They have requested a group loan of 40,000 AFN in order to support their families.

loans.use: To buy a new embroidery machine

loans.name: Gloria Marlene

texts.es:
la sra. Gloria R. tiene 50 años de edad, se dedica al comercio, vende zapatos, lociones, perfumes, cremas, vestidos para niñas. para esta epoca que navideña desea comprar mercaderia al por mayor, Gloria vende su producto en diferentes empresas privadas y estatales, desde ahorita le estan pidiendo el producto ya que con los pagos que reciben las personas le pagan.
ahora le estan ofreciendo varios productos al por mayor y desea comprarlos ya que estos se venden rapido.
Gloria es una persona muy amable y simpatica.
su trabajo la hace sentirse muy feliz.
texts.en:
Gloria R., 50, is a merchant who sells shoes, lotions, perfumes, beauty creams, girls' dresses. For this Christmas season she wants to buy merchandise at wholesale. Gloria sells her products to employees at various private and state-run enterprises and they are already asking for product as of today since they pay her with their salaries when they get paid. She is currently being offered products at wholesale and she wants to buy them because they sell out quickly. Gloria is a very nice and agreeable person. Her work makes her very happy.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shoes, sandals, perfumes, lotions, dresses, and beauty creams.

loans.name: Mercedes Liseth

texts.es:
En el departamento de Chinandega, la señora Mercedes Córdoba posee su propia pulpería donde ofrece todo tipo de productos como comestibles tales como arroz, azúcar, galletas, golosinas, pan, entre otros y también vende aceite y plátanos. De igual manera, ella vende productos como jabones, papel higienico, ase, pasta de dientes y otros.
Solicita el crédito para invertirlo en la compra de los productos para la pulpería y de esta manera continuar en su actividad buscando la manera de satisfacer las necesidades de todos sus clientes.
texts.en:
In the department of Chinandega, Sra. Mercedes Córdoba has her own grocery store where she offers all types of food products such as rice, sugar, cookies, candy, bread, cooking oil, and bananas. In addition, she sells products such as soap, toilet paper, cleaning products, toothpaste, and other items.

She is requesting a loan to buy more products for her grocery store so that she can continue her business. Mercedes looks for ways to satisfy all of her customers’ needs.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
A good entrepreneur dreams to improve her business, support the education of her children and improve the living conditions of her family. She also plans to buy a canter truck to hasten the delivery of her products to different locations. She is 34 year-old Yolanda D., who lives in the village of Brgy. Guimbala-on Silay City Negros Occidental.

Her husband Welfredo drives the jeep they own to deliver the soft drinks that they sell on a wholesale basis to different vendors around town. Yolanda also sells the soft drinks retail to her neighbors.

The couple has 4 children who are between 6 and 18 years old. They all go to school at present. Yolanda and Welfredo already had this business even before she joined NWTF Project Dungganon in 2006, but it was the need for more capital to fund their expanding operations that prompted her to join. With the help of her loans she is able to purchase larger quantities of soft drinks to distribute to a network of regular stores that they have developed a relationship with over the years.

To supplement their income, Yolanda also sells fruits, such as bananas, and used clothes in the store adjacent to her house. She earns about PHP 9,550 from her business activities and it helps a lot in paying for the education of her children and defraying the household expenses while allowing her to save up for the future.

In her previous loan Php 23,000, she used it as additional working capital for her wholesale and retailing of soft drinks. The said amount was fully paid within her loan term, and contributed to the maintenance of her good credit performance with NWTF-Project Dungganon. Now she borrowing for her 8th cycle loan the amount of Php 25,000 which she intends to use to fund the buying and selling of bananas and purchase soft drinks in bulk. The income from it will be used to take the next steps in her journey toward the fulfillment of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project "Dungganon" (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them "Dungganon" -- a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Martha Auxiliadora

texts.es: La señora Martha A. se ha destacado por ser una persona que se preocupa por el bienestar de su hijo y también por mantener a su mamá ya que está a su cargo y la cuida y protege. Ella trabaja diario y ha tomado la decisión de invertir en el mejoramiento de su vivienda porque esta ha estado en condiciones malas. Por esta razón es que solicita un crédito con el propósito de invertirlo en la compra de los materiales de construcción y así dar lugar a la reconstrucción de su casa de habitación ubicada en el departamento de Masaya donde ella vive y trabaja.
texts.en:
Martha A. stands out as a person who is very concerned about her son's well-being and also that of her mother, who is in her care and whom she looks after and protects. She works every day, and she has made the decision to invest in improving her home, which has been in poor condition. For this reason, she is requesting a loan with the aim of purchasing construction materials to renovate her house, located in the Department of Masaya, where she lives and works.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing building materials

loans.name: Chan's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan P. is 48 years old and she is the village bank president of this group that consists of eighteen people located in Krang Pou village in Takeo province. The members will each use their loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Chan P. is widow with two children both of whom are attending the local school.

Mrs. Chan P. is a farmer who owns 5-hectare (12.5-acre) field on which she cultivates rice, but she now faces some problems because her field has infertile soil and the water is far from the irrigation system. Thus, she decided to ask for the loan to buy fertilizer and to hire the laborer to plow her field. The rest of the loan she would use to pay for pumping water to her rice field.

Mrs. Chan P. hopes that the loan will help her to improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, to hire the laborer to plow her field and to pay for pumping water to her rice field

loans.name: Maria Doroliza

texts.es:
Maria Doroliza C. tiene 36 años de edad, su estado civil es union libre, y vive con sus 6 hijos.

La socia es un miembro de la ventanilla rural "Juntos Venceremos Comunidad" la cual está ubicada en la comunidad de Santa Deriana perteneciente al cantón Chillanes.  La mayoría de los socios cultivan arroz, maíz, naranja, y cacao en el clima subtrópico como la principal fuente de ingresos.

Maria se dedica a la agricultura desde hace casi toda la vida.  Siembra yuca, cacao, maiz, verde, naranja.  Enfrenta mucho desafíos en trabajar en la agricultura, uno de ellos es el hongo que a veces afecta a los cultivos de cacao.  También se dedica a la crianza de animales domesticos como gallinas, patos, y chanchos.  Realiza las ventas de sus productos en la parroquia Matilde.  Solicita el crédito para invertir en la siembra de cacao.

Su sueño es mejorar su vivienda y darles a todos sus hijos el estudio para que sean todos unos profesionales.  Cuando no está trabajando, le gusta ir de visita a la casa de sus padres.
texts.en:
Maria Doroliza C., 36, is in a common law marriage and lives with her six children. She is a member of the Juntos Venceremos Communidad communal bank. It is located in the Santa Deriana community, which belongs to the Chillanes canton. Most of the members grow rice, corn, oranges, and cocoa in its subtropical climate. It is their main source of income. Maria has devoted herself to agriculture for almost her entire life. She plants yucca, cocoa, corn, vegetables, and oranges. She faces many challenges in her agricultural work. One of them is the fungus that sometimes affects the cocoa crops. She also raises domestic animals like hens, ducks, and pigs. She sells her products in the Matilde parish. She is asking for the loan to invest in planting cocoa. Her dream is to improve her home and give all of her children an education so that they will become professionals. When she is not working she likes to go to her parents’ house to visit.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in planting cocoa

loans.name: Marites' Group

texts.en:
Marites C. is from the village of Parug-Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She is thirty-eight years old. Marites is the group leader of a twelve-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marites is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns and operates a furniture-making business in the manufacturing sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling dining furniture to local businesses and community members. Marites has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This loan will be Marites's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Mr. Long K., age 35, and his wife, Mrs. Sophak Moung, 36, have been married since 1999 and have four daughters -- all of them in school. They  live along National Road Number Six about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. The photo is of Sophak.

Long has been driving a Tuk Tuk taxi in Phnom Penh for a year. His wife stays at home and does housework. Unhappily, his Tuk Tuk is old and does not work well. This makes it difficult for him because the taxi is his only source of income. This is why Long is requesting his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a new Tuk Tuk to replace the old one.

loans.use: To purchase new Tuk Tuk taxi to replace the old one.

loans.name: Susan Halima

texts.en:
Susan is a 29 year old woman married to Mohemed.  They have two children. She is in the business of selling water in Kisumu Ndogo-Malindi where she targets households within the area. Her business is four years old and she gets a monthly profit of 8,000 KES. Apart from the water business, Susan also sells charcoal as a secondary business.

Susan was introduced to KADET by a friend and this is her first loan. She will utilize this loan by adding stock of charcoal worth 5,000 KES and purchase water pipes as well as add a third tap to boost her business with the other 5,000 KES. With the extra profit, she plans to complete rental houses at her plot.

A hardworking woman, Susan hopes to own a big business specializing in charcoal.

loans.use: Add stock of charcoal, purchase water pipes and add another tap

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.es:
Tienda la Flor de Oro es un lugar de gran preferencia entre los vecinos del barrio Carrizal en el sur de Barranquilla, pues su propietaria Ernestina C. R. de 52 años, es una mujer valiente que ofrece una atención esmerada a cada persona que se acerca a este negocio, que le ha dado todo y al que se ha entregado también, desde el mismo momento en que quedó viuda con sus tres hijos y responsable de todos los ingresos y decisiones del hogar; a través de su esfuerzo, dedicación ha logrado que sus hijos estudien y ya hay uno que es profesional y con ello tiene su familia, un nuevo ingreso para solventar los gastos del hogar. El negocio de Ernestina es resolver las necesidades de las familias vecinas, relacionadas con el acceso a productos de la canasta familiar, por eso necesita un crédito por valor de $ 2.300.000, para invertirlo en la  compra de aceite en pimpina, arroz, granos, bebidas y carnes especialmente. Este es su tercer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con los créditos recibidos de esta organización, ha logrado incrementar sus ventas y apoyar el crecimiento educativo de sus hijos. Su sueño es lograr que los dos hijos, aún bachilleres, sean profesionales ya que esta posibilidad le augura un futuro mejor. 
Ernestina se esmera por aumentar la excelencia en el servicio a su clientela para lograr la sostenibilidad en el mercado y aumentar cada día sus ingresos. El desafío más grande fue quedar sola con sus tres hijos después del fallecimiento de su esposo  y ampliar la capacidad de recibir créditos para ofrecer una mejor oferta de productos a sus clientes.
texts.en:
The store "La Flor de Oro" enjoys a strong patronage from the neighbors of the Carrizal neighborhood in the southern part of Barranquilla. The owner, Ernestina C. R., 52, is a stout-hearted woman who provides careful attention to every person who enters this business, which has given her everything and to which she has dedicated herself. Ever since she was left a widow with 3 children, she has been responsible for all of the income and decisions of the home. Through her efforts she has managed to put her children through school. Already one of them is a professional, and he has a family and a new income to cover the household expenses. Ernestina's business meets the needs of neighboring families, who use it to access grocery products that are typically bought by local households. She needs a loan in the amount of $2.3 million Colombian pesos to invest in the purchase of cooking oil, rice, grains, drinks, and meats, in particular. This is her 3rd loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo; with the loans she has taken from this organization she has managed to increase her sales and support the education of her children. Her dream is to see her two unmarried children become professionals and have the possibility of a better future. Ernestina takes great care to improve the services to her customers so that her business will be sustainable in the market and her income will increase over time. Her greatest challenge was being left alone with 3 children after the death of her husband. She wants to expand her ability to receive credit so that she can provide a better offering of products to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy cooking oil, rice, grains, drinks and meat

loans.name: Buzaniro Women's Group A, Kihihi

texts.en:
There is a fascinating story behind determined M. Alfred who was not afraid of diversity when he ventured into the business world ten years ago. This hardworking, married father of four children began his produce shop, dealing in general food crops like beans, maize flour, groundnuts (peanuts), peas and many other items in Kibaya, Kihihi.

Through acquiring loans from micro-finance institutions, Alfred was able to start up this side business alongside his agriculture to help him bring more income into the family. With this loan Alfred will be able to purchase more stock and be able to improve his earnings as he looks forward to live a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Luz Del Milagro

texts.es:
Luz es una madre de familia de 29 años de edad, tiene un hijo y vive junto a su esposo en el distrito de Santa Rosa, una distrito cuya economía depende principalmente de la pesca, se encuentra ubicado a veinticinco minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace mas de cinco años a la venta de ropa para damas, caballeros y niños. Ella vende prendas de vestir al crédito y al contado y las comercializa de acuerdo a pedidos. Su mercadería la compra en la ciudad de Lima. Con los ingresos que percibe de esta actividad ella ayuda a su esposo a solventar los gastos familiares.

Luz desea adquirir mas ropa para aumentar sus ventas aprovechando la cercanía de las fiestas en su distrito. Por ello ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en el logro de su objetivo.

Luz es una persona tranquila y muy entregada a su familia. Su mayor anhelo es seguir trabajando para instalar un pequeño bazar en su vivienda. Su carisma y buen trato le han hecho conocida entres sus vecinos y clientes.
texts.en:
Luz, 29, is a young mother. She lives with her husband and son in Santa Rosa district, a district that depends primarily on fishing. It is located 25 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. For over 5 years she has sold clothing for women, men and children. She sells both on credit and for cash. She sells based on prior orders. She buys her merchandise in Lima. Profits from her business help her husband meet family expenses. Luz would like to acquire more clothes to increase sales taking advantage of the approaching feast days in her district. She is, therefore, asking Edpyme Alternativa for her first, 1000 new sol, loan to be used to meet this goal. Luz is a calm person who is very dedicated to her family. Her greatest wish is to continue working so that she can set up a small store in her home. Her charisma and good interpersonal skills have made her very well-known among her neighbors and customers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy construction material such as cement, iron, timber and zinc for home improvements

loans.name: Rosally

texts.en:
This is Rosally D. C., 23, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Roberto D. C. and is the mother of a toddler.
 
Rosally operates a soft drink business. She bulk buys cases of assorted soft drinks then supplies variety stores in the immediate area. Because not many variety stores are big enough to order their own supply, this arrangement works out pretty well. Rosally’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a 34,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy larger quantities of products to incorporate into her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands the business.  

Rosally dreams of having her own house, lot and car one day from all her hard work with the business.

loans.use: to buy larger quantities of products

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine R. lives in Saac I, LLC, Brgy. Buaya, Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu, where she earns her living by operating two business ventures: general store and videoke (video karaoke) businesses. Her husband, Samuel R., 46, works as a carpenter, and they have five children ranging in age from 13 to 26 years old.

Josephine joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 13000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 13000, thereby uplifting the family's standard of living. In order to continue to save up for her planned business expansion, Josephine is requesting her sixth loan in the amount of PHP 17000 as additional working capital for her enterprises. Josephine R. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additonal working capital

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy B. is from the town of Villa Rose Cabarroguis, Quirino. She is 31 years old. Mercy is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Mercy owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Mercy has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mercy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mercy is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Mercy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jaqueline Vanessa

texts.es:
Jacqueline es socia del Banco Comunal “Flor de Kantuta” desde hace nueve meses atrás, está ubicado en la Provincia  Yunguyo, departamento de Puno, tiene 20 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, con grado de instrucción secundaria completo, tiene un niño de año y medio.
Se dedica a la elaboración de canastas desde hace dos años atrás y las distribuye al por mayor en la feria de Juliaca, los días lunes. Con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, que fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles  pudo  aumentar su capital.
Solicitará  un nuevo crédito de S/. 1000.00 nuevos soles, para comprar materiales de elaboración de canastas.   
Su visión es ampliar  su negocio en otros departamentos del país. Lo que más le gusta de su Banquito Comunal es la forma de trabajo de su promotora.
texts.en:
Jacqueline, 20, has been a member of the “Flor de Kantuta” communal bank for the last 9 months. It is located in Yunguyo province, Puno department. She lives with her life partner and finished secondary school. She has an 18-month-old son. She has made baskets for the last two years that she sells at wholesale in the Juliaca market on Mondays. She used her first, 500 new sol, loan from Manuela Ramos Movement to increase her capital. She will ask for a new, 1000 new sol loan, to buy basket weaving raw materials. Her vision is to expand her business into other departments in the country. What she enjoys most about her communal bank is her advisor’s way of working.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basket weaving supplies.

loans.name: Vũ

texts.en:
T. Vũ Thị (20213050018) is a 35 year-old female living in the town of huyện Yên Phong.  She is married and has 3 school-aged children.  To making a living, T. owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling pork products in the local community.  T. has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, T. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,048,000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  T. is now requesting a new loan of 8,736,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business.  The loan will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA.  T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand the business.

About SEDA:
The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nazila

texts.ru:
Nazila A. 49 let. Ona zamujem i imeyet 3 detey. Nazila yavlyayetsya IDP personom ona pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda, seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione. 

Nazila uje 5 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom skotovodstva. Etomu biznessu ona nauchilas u svoyey mami. Nazila derjit korov i prodayet ix moloko i delayet sir. Seychas ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovu  dlya uvelicheniya kolichestva produkta.
texts.en:
Nazila A. is 49 years old.  She is married and has three children.  Nazila is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person).  She is a refugee from the city of Fuzuli who now lives in the Fuzuli region.

Nazila has been working as a cowherd for five years.  She started this business with her mother.  Nazila keeps cows, sells their milk, and makes cheese.  Currently, she need 2000 AZN to buy a cow which will enhance the quality of her product.

loans.use: Buying a cow
